abstract: Supreme Court declines to rule in case on whether religious groups should offer insurance coverage for contraception to their female employees, and instructs lower courts to consider whether compromise is possible; some religious employers argue that providing coverage, as ordinarily required by regulation under Affordable Care Act, makes them complicit in what they consider to be sinful conduct.

headline.print_headline: Court Sidesteps Contraception, Avoiding a Tie
headline.main: Justices, Seeking Compromise, Return Contraception Case to Lower Courts

keywords.value: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
keywords.name: subject

snippet: The case was brought by religious groups that objected to having to provide insurance coverage for contraception for their female employees.
lead_paragraph: The case was brought by religious groups that objected to having to provide insurance coverage for contraception for their female employees.
